instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image/backlight
threads.message:
Hello again!,
Have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no image/backlight, no signs of liquid damage, boards look very clean. Tried different lcd, external, no image and no backlight on both. Tried to connect mouse for USB activity check, but there is no light coming on from mouse.
Board gets 20V and 0.6A
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>  3.3V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD_R</SIGNAL> 0.99V
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_CPUVCC</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>  3.2V
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image/backlight
threads.message:
No reason to search for video, if no USB activity at least.

There should be some history fault.
Try known good BIOS.
